author: ansgar.eth
content: Sure! So basically: Currently, mining software can be quite simple, because it just sorts all transactions it could include into the next block by payment, and then includes as many of them into the block as possible. This is the way geth implements it, anf you canâ€™t really do any better if you would write your own mining software. The exception to that is of course MEV, where running modified mining software (namely mev-geth) is significantly more profitable. But at least mev-geth is open source. We really donâ€™t want a situation where miners can have a big advantage by running some proprietary smart algorithm, because that would lead to centralization pressures over time.

author: ansgar.eth
content: And so a concern with 4488 was: Because we now have 2 separate limits per block (calldata and gas), packing a block optimally with transactions could theoretically become a highly complicated challenge, and thus open the door to more profitable proprietary software. So I looked at how far from the theoretical optimum different strategies are. And turns out, there is this backlog method that gets you really close in profitability to that optimum. So as long as geth (and for after the merge all the other execution clients) just implement that one, that removes any incentive for people to write their own versions, and so removes that potential centralization pressure.
